title.narrative: Reconstruction of past hydrological change and vegetation dynamics in south-east Africa using isotope signatures in biomarkers
Rekonstruktion av paleo-hydrologi och vegetationsdynamik i syd-östra Afrika genom isotop-analyser på biomarkörer

description.narrative: This anthropological project focuses on identity formation among refugees, in particular among refugee youth, in relation to an ongoing humanitarian intervention. Taking the case of UN-run education in the Palestinian occupied territories, the project wishes to investigate long-term and large-scale intervention and its local responses. The overall aim is to understand and analyze local experiences of and responses to two programs in UNRWA schools (i.e. Human Rights Education and Respect and Discipline in Violence Free Schools) and how refugees relate those to national identity-formation, state-building, national independence and international understandings of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The study will provide new ethnographic data about camp life and refugee schooling and theoretical insights about identity formation in relation to aid intervention and refugee labelling.

Tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world are highly significant for global climate variability as they generate heat and water vapour that is distributed within the global hydrological cycle. Still, regional-scale climate and hydrological reconstructions are sparse in these regions, and available records are often contradictory, lacking quantitative proxies. The main focus of the proposed project is to reconstruct climate and vegetation change in south-eastern Africa, an area where high-quality paleo-records are extremely sparse. Our objectives are to: 1) generate quantitative records of past hydrological change, such as rainfall seasonality and variability, and thereby detect past large-scale atmospheric circulation dynamics, and 2) reconstruct temperature-related fluxes in the vegetation cover, particularly within the grassland biome. Methodical applications involve new powerful bio-chemical technology; hydrogen (dD) and carbon (d13C) isotope analysis on plant-derived biomarkers, so called n-alkanes, that will be extracted from available, well-dated, sediment cores from lakes and wetlands in South Africa and Mozambique. Biomarker screening, i.e. analysing the inherent concentration of each n-alkane, will assist in interpretation and evaluation of the isotope records. A generous dating approach will optimize inter-data comparison and reveal important regional climate excursions with up to decadal age-accuracy during the last 18 000 years that our records embrace.

participating-org.narrative: University, college or other teaching institution, research institute or think-tank
